theText: The answer to the honour(5) No. The Australian Roads Survey is not complete, so that no report has yet been made. I should point out the report will be to assist the Commonwealth in determining its policies in respect of the granting of financial assistance to the States for roads when the current Commonwealth Aid Roads Act expires in 1974. (6) As I have already stated in answer to a previous question, I understand that the New South Wales Government has received such a report and has decided not to release it at this time. National Parks: Ministerial Conference (Question No. 6095) Mr Whitlam asked the Minister for the Interior, upon notice: (1) When and where was the sixth Ministerial Conference on National Parks held. (2) What were the names and portfolios of the Ministers who attended. (3) What requests or suggestions were made for legislative or administrative action by (a) the Comfor some other reason. monwealth, (b) the Territories and (c) the States. member's question is as follows: (1) The Sixth Ministerial Conference on National Parks was held in Sydney, New South Wales on 22nd June 1972. (2) and (3) As the conference is preponderantly one of State Ministers established by State initiatives, it is suggested that the honourable member direct any inquiries concerning the conference to the Conference Secretariat, c/The Director, National Parks and Wild Life Service, Sydney' New South Wales. The Minister for the Interior attended; the Minister for External Territories was unable to attend. Unemployment: Relief Grants to States (Question No. 6144) Mr Grassby asked the Treasurer, upon notice: (1) What sum was dispersed in unemployment relief grants to each State up to 30th June 1972. (2) What agencies in New South Wales received unemployment relief moneys, what sums did they receive and where were the agencies located. able member's question is as follows: (1) The following amounts were paid to each State under the non-metropolitan unemployment relief scheme from the commencement of the scheme in December 1971 to 30th June 1972: New South Wales Victoria Queensland South Australia Western Australia Tasmania Total* Actual amount paid to Western Australia in 1971-72 was $600 less than this amount due to accounting error; the $600 has since been paid to the State. (2) This information is not available from Commonwealth sources but an endeavour is being made to obtain it from New South Wales authorities. Election Proposals: Cost (Quc-tion No. 6186) Mr Hayden asked the Treasurer, upon notice: (1) Does his answer to question No. 5770 (Hansard, 30th May 1972, page 3306) imply that the Government feels no need to be informed on the Australian Democratic Labor Party's election proposals. (2) If so, is this because the Government regards them to be so irresponsible and extreme as to be not worthy of consideration or because the Government regards the Party to be so insignificant as to be not worthy of attention or (3) If not, and in view of his statement that it is the proper function of any Government to be adequately informed on details (including costs) of policy proposals being advanced by individuals and groups in the community, including political parties, why were the election proposals of thc Australian Democratic Labor Party not costed. ourable member's question is as follows: (1) No. (2) See answer to (1). (3) What constitutes adequate information is a matter of judgment and depends on circumstances. The Government regarded itself as adequately informed on the matters in question. Social Services (Question No. 6192) Mr Hayden asked the Minsterf o r Social Services, upon notice: (1) Did he give an undertaking on 22nd February 1972 that the increases in rates provided under thc Social Services Bill (subsequently Act No. 1 of 1972) would operate without delay, that is, in respect of the benefit week ending on the date in which the Royal Assent was obtained, and to each benefit week thereafter. (2) Did he also state that the proposed increase would also apply to short-term sickness benefits and to special benefits. (3) If so, has his attention been drawn to an inter oflice memorandum dated l l t h April 1972, $ reference number A8392/JMM*as, from the .. 10,395,000 Director-General of Social Services which referred .. .. 6,075,000 to an earlier memorandum of 25th February 1972, .. .. 5,400,000 reference number A8392/62. .. 1,620,000 (4) Did the earlier memorandum advise that the .. 2,025,000* increases provided in the rates of unemployment .. .. 1,485,000 benefit and short term sickness benefit were, for the time being, not to apply to persons caring for .. .. 27,000,000 invalid parent(s) or relativc(s) and a male caring for a sick wife and/or children.

theText: The answer to the hon(5) Did tbe later memorandum advise that fhe matter referred to in part (4) had been reviewed, that it had been decided to increase the maximum rate for these categories to the equivalent of the maximum rates of unemployment benefit and that the increases were to apply in respect of all benefit weeks ending on the day following receipt of the memorandum. Payment of the increases to this class of dicting the undertaking given to the Australian public by the Minister on 22nd February 1972. (7) Why did the Director-General amend the instruction on llth April 1972 to provide for the increase in special benefits from a date in April and not as promised by the Minister. (8) On what date did the Bill receive the Royal Assent. (9) From what date were the increases in special benefits actually provided. (11) What are the usual grounds on which special benefit is sought by applicants and is it a line. fact that in many cases recipients of special benefits save the Commonwealth considerable money because they care for invalided persons receiving the low benefit rate of 817 a week compared to, for instance, CommonweaUh bed day subsidy lor nursing home attention for an invalid of $45.50 a week. ourable member's question is as follows: (1) to (11) In accordance with the undertaking which I gave to the Parliament on 22nd February 1972, the rates of special benefit were increased with effect from the benefit week ending on 25th February, the date of Royal Assent. At that time, however, certain proposals were under consideration which would have affected the position of persons receiving special benefit because they were required to care for invalid relspecial beneficiary, which was deferred until these proposals had been fully considered, was authorised, with full arrears, as soon as practicable in the circumstances. The Parliament: Air Travel Cost (Question No. 6195) Mr Charles Jones asked the Minister for the Interior, upon notice: (1) What was the cost of (a) domestic and (b) internauonal air travel for Senators and Members able. (2) What was the break-up between each airable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) Separate records are not kept of Members' travel by individual airlines so the information in the form sought by the honourable member is not readily available. However, the overall cost of air travel as a charge against the Members Travel vote for the financial year 197172 was $763,378.
